facts.fact: Its population was 1730 at the 2020 census.
Advance was founded c.
The town is pronounced ADD-vance.
The community is still commonly referred to as "Stone's Corner," as the intersection of Route 43 and Route 171 is known.
It is also the largest city in Gentry County, with a population of 1679 at the 2020 census.
As of the 2020 census, its population was 105.
In 2024, the city voted to disincorporate.
As of the 2020 census, its population was 24.
The town was officially incorporated in 1919.
A suburb of St. Louis, the city lies within the Greater St. Louis metropolitan statistical area.
The entire village is part of the National Historic Landmark Arrow Rock Historic District, designated by the Department of the Interior, National Park Service in 1963.
The town is well known for the Arrow Rock Lyceum Theatre, hosting over 33000 patrons every year.
Several locations are also certified sites of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail and the Santa Fe National Historic Trail.
The first state-designated historic site is located here.
Restoration of a 19th-century tavern in 1923 marked the beginning of historic preservation in Missouri.
Many structures within the village are individually listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
The town has numerous bed and breakfast establishments, and a modern campground nearby is maintained by the Missouri Division of State Parks.
The village retains much of its 19th-century Boonslick character, and it attracts more than 100000 visitors per year.
It is significant in the history of Westward Expansion, the Santa Fe Trail, and 19th-century artist George Caleb Bingham.
Given the importance of heritage tourism to the village's economy, architectural ordinances implemented in 2004 provide guidance for both new construction and restorations of existing structures.
Ashland is part of the Columbia, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
The city has wineries, antique shops, restaurants, B&B's, a wood shop, a glass studio, massage therapy, a historic museum, and The Augusta Brewery.
Augusta is located in the region known as the Missouri Rhineland.
Augusta is a popular stop along the Katy Trail, a 225-mile-long bike and walking path built along a former railroad right-of-way.

The Augusta viticultural area was recognized by the federal government in 1980 as the first established American Viticultural Area (AVA) in the United States, two months prior to Napa Valley's recognition.
As a result, it is home to two wineries, Augusta Winery and Mount Pleasant Winery.
Vineyards and wineries have grown over the decades with more than 125 wineries now in the state of Missouri.

Starting in 2020, David Hoffmann and the Hoffmann Family of Companies have invested to grow the region into a wine-tourism destination and have purchased more than two dozen properties, including four wineries and six vineyards.
As of the 2020 census, the population of the city was 7217.
The city was founded in 1871.
It was renamed Ava in 1881, the town's original name having been Militia Springs.
Avilla is the fourth-oldest settlement in Jasper County today, founded in 1856.
It was platted and laid out for public use July 23, 1858, by Andrew L. Love and David S. Holman.
Ballwin is a western suburb of St. Louis in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
Its population was 31103 as of the 2020 census.

Baring is located on the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe railroad's mainline between Chicago and Los Angeles, which can carry heavy mixed freight and intermodal traffic, as well as Amtrak's Southwest Chief passenger train.
As of the 2020 census, its population is 125.
As of the 2020 census, the city population was 201.
Barnhart is also a suburb of St. Louis.
As of the 2020 census, the city's population was 5990.
Bel-Nor is a northwestern suburban city of St. Louis in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
Bel-Ridge is part of the Normandy Schools Collaborative.
Bel-Ridge became a city in 2015 by a vote of the voters.
It was founded as a sawmill town circa 1900, and lies at the foothills of Crowley's Ridge on Missouri Route 91.
Dorothy Burton is the current mayor.
As of the 2020 census, the city population was 757.
The Osage County portion of Belle is part of the Jefferson City, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Bellefontaine Neighbors ( bel-FOWN-tən) is an inner-ring suburban city in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
Much of the former golf course is now occupied by the University of Missouri–St. Louis.
In April, 2015, the residents voted to change the village of Bellerive to a fourth class city named Bellerive Acres.
It is the former site of Bellerive Country Club, which relocated southwest to Town and Country in 1959.
Berkeley is an inner-ring suburb of St. Louis in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
Portions of St. Louis Lambert International Airport are within the city limits.
As of the 2020 census, the city population was 475.
It is also adjacent to Big Lake State Park, which has the largest marsh in a state park in the state of Missouri.
A post office called Black Jack was established in 1872, and operated until 1906.
The community was named for a grove of blackjack oak trees near the original town site.
Black Jack is a second-ring suburb of St. Louis in northern St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
Founded by the Missouri Pacific Railroad, Blackwater's economy was largely defined by freight until the mid-twentieth century.
The city has preserved a number of historic, rail-related structures that have been repurposed as museums, hotels, or antique shops.
Many parts of Blackwater's commercial and residential districts are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
With the railroad's decline, Blackwater's status as a boom town came to an end, and the population thinned considerably.
A post office called Blackwells Station was established in 1858, and the name was changed to Blackwell in 1885.
A variant name was "Blackwell Station".
The community has the name of Lavinia Blackwell and Margaret Blackwell, first settlers.
Senator Earl R. Blackwell grew up near Blackwell.
The Osage County portion of Bland is part of the Jefferson City, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
In September 1864 during the Civil War, the town was reduced to ashes.
Genevieve County, Missouri, United States.
Blue Eye, Missouri is adjacent to Blue Eye, Arkansas.
Blue Springs is located 19 miles (31 km) east of Kansas City.
As of the 2020 census, the population was 58604.
The city derives its name in-part from the South American revolutionary Simón Bolívar.
According to the 2020 United States Census, Bolivar had a population of 10772.
The city was the site of a skirmish early in the Civil War, on July 17, 1861.
Union forces defeated the Missouri State Guard in the first Battle of Boonville.
At the time of the 2010 census, it had a population of 1632.
Branson is the site of the Branson Cross, the largest cross monument in North America.
The community was named after Reuben Branson, postmaster and operator of a general store in the area in the 1880s.

The collection of entertainment theaters along 76 Country Boulevard (and to a lesser extent along Shepherd of the Hills Expressway), including Dolly Parton's Stampede, has increased Branson's popularity as a tourist destination.
Branson is in the Ozark Mountains.
Most of the city is situated in Taney County, with a small portion in the west extending into Stone County.
Branson has long been a popular destination for vacationers from Missouri and around the country.
Brentwood is an inner-ring suburb of St. Louis in Clayton Township, St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
The town is featured in the documentary Atomic Homefront, which covers the effects of radioactive waste stored in the nearby West Lake Landfill site.
Bridgeton is a second-ring suburb of Greater St. Louis in northwestern St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
Bridgeton is located at the intersection of the St. Louis outer belt and I-70.
Bridgeton serves as the primary transport hub within Greater St. Louis.
Portions of St. Louis Lambert International Airport are within Bridgeton.
The post office was established in 1895.
Bruner is part of the Springfield, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
A post office is located in Bruner on the north side of Route 14.
James A. Rathbun moved to the region in 1862 and settled near Keltner.
About two years later he moved and established a store and post office near the current location of Bruner.
He established a post office and settled on the name of Bruner after his first choice, Rathbun, was denied because a Rathbun office was already in use.
Its population was 801 at the 2020 census.
Brunswick, by official state proclamation, is the Pecan Capital of Missouri.
The Missouri Farmers Association (MFA Incorporated) was founded in Brunswick in 1914.
For decades it was best known for TV and radio commercials promoting local automobile dealership Lasater Ford, run by the Lasater brothers, Wilson and Milton and later Halverson Ford.
The city is named for William Orlando Butler, an American military and political figure of the early and mid-19th century.
Cadet is located on Missouri Route 47 between Old Mines to the west and Bonne Terre to the southeast.
The village is approximately 6 miles (10 km) northeast of Potosi.
The pronunciation is Kay-row, unlike the city in Egypt.
Caledonia is located 4 miles (6.4 km) east of Belgrade.
As of the 2020 census the population was 4498.
The Village of Calverton Park incorporated as the City of Calverton Park in 2014.
The city is enveloped by the Lower Niangua arm of the Lake of the Ozarks, and serves as a popular trade point for visitors to the area.
Its population was 3718 at the 2010 census.
Canton is the home of Culver-Stockton College, a small liberal arts college affiliated with the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ).
It also had the oldest continuously operating ferry across the Mississippi River, which closed in April 2014.
Four members of the United States House of Representatives have come from Canton, and are buried in the city's Forest Grove Cemetery.
The community most likely was named for the river cape or sharp stream meander south of the original town site.
Cape Fair is on the west side of the James River arm of Table Rock Lake.
A post office called Cape Fair has been in operation since 1851.
Cape Girardeau is the economic center of southeastern Missouri and the home of Southeast Missouri State University.
Cape Girardeau ( jirr-AR-doh, French: Cap-Girardeau ; colloquially referred to as "Cape") is a city in Cape Girardeau and Scott counties in the U S state of Missouri.
The community was named after Frank Cardwell, an Arkansas banker who lent money to the town's founders.
The 2024 recorded population is 526.
The current mayor of Cardwell is Denise Latting and the current aldermen are Cody Todd, Dustin Lee and Winnia Cohea.
Lisa Vowels serves as the City Clerk.
Carrollton won the 2005 All-America City Award, given out annually by the National Civic League.
According to the 2020 census, the population of Cassville was 3186.
Cassville is one of the primary markets and job centers for an estimated 14000 people living in the surrounding area.
Catawissa was laid out in 1858, and most likely was named after Catawissa, Pennsylvania.
Winch Creek flows past the eastern margin of the community.
A post office called Catawissa has been in operation since 1860.
The Ozark County line lies just to the west of Caulfield.
A very small portion of the city lies in Audrain County.
It is near the Mark Twain National Forest.
The community most likely was named for cherry trees near the original town site.
A post office called Cherryville has been in operation since 1862.
The broader valley of Chesterfield was originally referred to as "Gumbo Flats", derived from its soil, which though very rich and silty, resembled gumbo when wet.
It is a western suburb of St. Louis.
As of the 2020 census, the population was 49999, making it the state's 14th most populous city.
Chesnutridge is part of the Springfield, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
It is on Missouri Route BB just east of Missouri Route 176 and about two miles west of U S Route 65.
A post office called Chestnutridge has been in operation since 1902.
The community takes its name from a nearby ridge of the same name where chestnut trees were abundant.
Chillicothe is known as "The Home of Sliced Bread".
For many years its schools were segregated and African American students attended what eventually became known as Garrison School, named after William Lloyd Garrison.
The name "Chillicothe" is Shawnee for "big town".
Organized in 1877, the city was named after Ralph Clayton, a citizen who donated the land for the St. Louis County courthouse.
Clever, like the rest of Christian County, saw a significant increase in population between 2000 and 2010.
It is home to the Benedictine Convent of Perpetual Adoration which houses 550 documented saint relics—one of the largest collections in the United States.
As of the 2020 census, the population was 264, up from 226 in 2010.
The town is known for the annual street fair in September.
It also hosts a Maifest in May, an Oktoberfest in October, and a Christbaumfest in late November; all highlight the town's German heritage.

Surrounding Columbia is a greenbelt including Rock Bridge Memorial State Park, Eagle Bluffs Conservation Area, the Mark Twain National Forest, Katy Trail State Park, Finger Lakes State Park, and the Big Muddy National Fish and Wildlife Refuge.
In addition to the university and surrounding Downtown Columbia are Stephens College and Columbia College, giving the city its educational focus and nearly 40000 college students.
It was founded in 1821 and had a population of 126254 as recorded in the 2020 United States census, making it the fourth-most populous city in Missouri.
Columbia is among the most-educated cities in the United States with about half of citizens being college graduates and about a quarter holding advance degrees.
The city is built on the oak-forested hills and rolling prairies of Mid-Missouri, near the Missouri River, where the Ozark Mountains transition into plains and savanna.
The University of Missouri Health Care system operates six hospitals in Columbia, several clinics, and the Thompson Center for Autism and Neurodevelopment.

There is also the county-owned Boone Hospital Center, several smaller private hospitals, and the Harry S. Truman Memorial Veterans' Hospital, adjacent to University Hospital and MU School of Medicine.
The University of Missouri nuclear reactor is the most-powerful research reactor in the United States and the sole supplier of important radioisotopes used in nuclear medicine.
The Missouri Tigers, the state's only major college athletic program, play football at Faurot Field and basketball at Mizzou Arena as members of the Southeastern Conference (SEC).
The city has been known as the "Athens of Missouri" for its educational emphasis and classic beauty, but is more commonly called "CoMo".
It should not be confused with Concord Township, which the CDP shares much land with, but these areas' boundaries are not identical.
Conway is located 15 miles (24 km) southwest of Lebanon.
The village is named for Erastus Corning who owned sizeable shares of the Chicago, Burlington, and Quincy Railroad and who is the namesake of another Burlington railroad community Corning, Iowa.
Corning was dissolved and disincorporated in 2023.
The village is considered the richest incorporated community in the state of Missouri ranked by mean household income as of 2020.
It is a gated neighborhood surrounded by Town and Country, Missouri.
In 2011, Bloomberg Businessweek magazine named Crestwood the "Best Place to Raise Kids in Missouri," lauding the community for top-tier schools and excellent municipal services.
It is home to the headquarters of Drury Hotels, and was the home of Monsanto until its acquisition by Bayer in 2018.
Its population was 18834 at the 2020 census.
Crystal City and its neighbor Festus are often collectively known as the "Twin Cities".
It was 4740 at the 2020 census.
Isaac Van Metre was first to settle in De Soto in the year of 1803.
The town was organized in 1857 and is named for the explorer Hernando De Soto, who claimed the Louisiana Territory for Spain.
De Soto was the city closest to the mean center of U S population in 1980.
The city celebrated its Bicentennial in 2003.
The city made national news on and after May 6, 2003, when straight-line winds and a tornado struck the junior high gymnasium.
As of the 2020 census, the population was 159.
The city encompasses a mostly residential area between Chambers Road and Interstate 270, as well a number of businesses along West Florissant Avenue.
Other than two churches and a post office, there are no services or any businesses in Denver: a half-block of storefront businesses still standing there are abandoned.
Dexter is a city in Stoddard County, Missouri, United States, founded in 1873.
Diamond is primarily renowned as the birthplace of George Washington Carver.
Diehlstadt was founded by John Kirkpatrick.
An 1891 railroad map calls the community "Dittmer's Store." It was officially named Dittmer in 1899.
The community's namesake is William Dittmer, an early postmaster who established a post office called Dittmer's Store in 1870.
Today, Dittmer is home to the Vianney Renewal Center, a treatment center for Catholic clergy with sexual or other disorders.

Interstate 44 and Interstate 49 run concurrently across the southeast corner of town, and Business Loop 44 runs through the center of town.
The Eagle Rock Retreat Center, home of the Assembly of God youth organizations Royal Rangers National Training Center, is located approximately 4 miles southwest of Eagle Rock.
As of the 2020 census, it had a population of 193.
Eagle Rock has a state campground and public marina.
A post office called Eagle Rock has been in operation since 1886.
The community takes its name from a nearby rock formation.
It is bounded by the city of Bridgeton on the east and north, the city of Maryland Heights to the south, and the Missouri River to the west.
It is also near Lambert International Airport.

Independence is a city mostly in and one of two county seats of Jackson County, Missouri, United States. It is a satellite city of Kansas City, Missouri, and is the largest suburb on the Missouri side of the Kansas City metropolitan area.
In 2020, it had a total population of 123,011, making it the fifth-most populous city in Missouri. A small part of the city extends into Clay County..
As of the 2020 census, its population was 1012.
In 2018, Elkland resident Helen Viola Jackson was inducted into the Missouri Walk of Fame Jackson was notable as the last living widow of a Civil War Veteran.
Elkland is part of the Springfield, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
A post office called Elkland has been in operation since 1870.
The community so named on account of the presence of elk near the original town site.
In 1987, Elkland resident James Schnick murdered seven of his relatives, and attempted to frame his nephew, Kirk Buckner, who was among his victims.
In 1925, the infamous Tri-State Tornado began just northwest of Ellington.
It is a western outer-ring suburb of St. Louis.
In 2009, Money magazine ranked Ellisville #25 on the annual Best Places to Live in America list.
The city is also currently home to an EPA Superfund site.

The community is located on a bend in the White River now Table Rock Lake.
Cassville is approximately 13 miles to the northwest and Rogers, Arkansas is 32 miles to the southwest.
It was incorporated in 1981.
The village is served by the Golden Post Office and thus has a Golden address.
Eugene was founded in 1904, and named after Eugene Simpson, the original owner of the town site.
As of the 2020 census, the population is 140.
A post office called Eugene has been in operation since 1904.
Since 1971, Eureka has been known as the home of the amusement park Six Flags St. Louis.
It is in the extreme southwest of the Greater St. Louis metro area.
As of the 2020 census, the city had a population of 11646.
It was named Twin Bridges at the 2000 census.
Ewing is part of the Lewis County C-1 School district.
Students attend the nearby Highland Elementary and Highland Junior-Senior High School.
Farmington was established in 1822 as Murphy's Settlement, named for William Murphy of Kentucky, who first visited the site in 1798.
It is in the Lead Belt region in Missouri.

When St. Francois County was organized, the town was briefly called St. Francois Court House and later renamed to Farmington.
The community is part of the St. Joseph, MO–KS Metropolitan Statistical Area.

It is a middle-class, second-ring northern suburb of St. Louis.

Forsyth is located on Lake Taneycomo on U S Route 160.
During World War II Italian and German POWs were interned at the fort.
Fort Leonard Wood is a U S Army training installation located in the Missouri Ozarks.
The main gate is located on the southern boundary of the city of St. Robert.
The post was created in December 1940 and named in honor of General Leonard Wood (former Chief of Staff) in January 1941.
Originally intended to train infantry troops, in 1941 it became an engineer training post with the creation of the Engineer Replacement Training Center.
In 1984, as part of the Base Realignment and Closure process, most of the U S Army Engineer School's operations were consolidated at Fort Leonard Wood.
Before that, officer training was conducted at Fort Belvoir, Virginia.

In 1999, again as part of the Base Realignment and Closure process, Fort McClellan, Alabama, was closed, and the U S Army Chemical Corps and Military Police Corps schools were transferred to Fort Leonard Wood, which was concurrently redesignated the U S Army Maneuver Support Center.

In 2009, the U S Army Maneuver Support Center was redesignated the U S Army Maneuver Support Center of Excellence (MSCoE); the "center of excellence" designation was placed on almost all U S Army training institutions.
The current commanding general is Major General Christopher G. Beck and the command sergeant major is Command Sergeant Major Jorge Arzabala.
Located in a rural area, the city had a population of 70 at the 2020 census.
As the eastern terminus of the Santa Fe Trail, the community played a major role in the westward expansion of the United States.
The city is surrounded on three sides (east, west, and south) by the easternmost parcel of the Mark Twain National Forest.
It is named after General John C. Fremont, who did some of the first surveys in the area as early as 1845.
Home to one of premiere golf courses in the area with a recreational area, pool, bar/restaurant at the Fremont Hills Country Club.
Located in Christian County, Missouri, it is situated just west of the CC & 65 highway interchange, one of the main highways to Branson, Missouri.
Christian County is one of the fastest growing counties in the state.
The city is ranked 324 in the state by size in the latest census with a growth rate of +4.10%.
Friedenswald is located in the central part of Camden County, Missouri on Lake Road 5-89.
Friedenswald is a village that was incorporated in 2008 and ratified by the Camden County, Missouri Commission under the Missouri Village Law.
The village is one of the smallest in the U S having a population of 2.
The community name is inspired by the New France governor Louis de Buade de Frontenac.
Benjamin and Lora Wood, who laid out the community's core called Frontenac Estates, that consisted of 26 two-acre estates, had made frequent trips to Quebec.
The community was incorporated as 217 acres (88 ha) in 1947 and annexed another 967 acres (391 ha) in 1948.
The community still consists mostly of houses on one-acre lots.
French architecture is encouraged in design.

The city is home to two universities, Westminster College and William Woods University; the Missouri School for the Deaf; the Fulton State Hospital; and the Fulton Reception and Diagnostic Center state prison.

Located about 22 miles (35 km) northeast of Jefferson City and the Missouri River and 20 miles (32 km) east of Columbia, the city is part of the Jefferson City, Missouri, Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Missouri's only nuclear power plant, the Callaway Plant is located 13 miles (21 km) southeast of Fulton.
Ginger Blue is an incorporated village in McDonald County, Missouri, United States.
The City of Gladstone is located about 10–20 minutes from downtown Kansas City, and about 10–20 minutes from Kansas City International Airport.
As of the 2020 census, the city population was 27063.
The Howard County portion of Glasgow is part of the Columbia, Missouri Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Glen Echo Park was a village in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
The community took its name from the nearby Glen Echo Country Club.
In August 2023, voters of Glen Echo Park and neighboring Normandy voted to consolidate the two municipalities.
The merger took effect on February 8, 2024, with Glen Echo Park being fully incorporated into Normandy.
The city is completely surrounded by the city of Liberty.
It was originally referred to as "Interurban Heights" or "Belleview" because of the interurban train that ran through the area and stopped at the Belleview depot near the Belleview Dairy.
As of the 2020 census, its population was 181.

It is 23 miles (37 km) east of downtown Kansas City.

Also called "Gray's Summit", it was founded by Daniel Gray of New York, who built a hotel here in 1845.

Greenville was incorporated and founded as the county seat of Wayne County in 1819.
It was located on Old Manchester Road (part of the original alignment of U S Route 66), but has now been wholly incorporated into Wildwood, whose City Hall is located in old Grover.

Southeast of the town is Mount Zion Church and Cemetery, the site of the Battle of Mount Zion Church during the Civil War.

It is known as the hometown of James Cash Penney, who built a large apparel-related business, J. C. Penney, and the hometown of Jenny Doan, who has built a large quilting-related business, Missouri Star Quilt Co.
According to the 2020 U S census, the population was 17108, making it the largest city in Marion County.
Nestled on the Mississippi River, commerce and traffic has long been an integral part of Hannibal's development, including by river, rail and the interstate/highway system.
The bulk of the city is in Marion County, with a tiny sliver in the south extending into Ralls County.
Today the city is intersected by Interstate 72 and U S Routes 24, 36, and 61.
Hannibal is not the county seat, but it has one of two county courthouses.
It was founded to be an important railroad depot, but the railroad never came and the town remained small.
Harrisburg is situated on a high point between Moniteau Creek and Perche Creek, at the headwaters of Callahan Creek.
It is named in honor of John Woods Harris, an early county leader and owner of the nearby “Model Farm” on Thrall’s Prairie.

It is near the center of the Missouri Rhineland and south of the Missouri River.
It has been the county seat since 1842.
Described as a Rhineland village, the city is the commercial center of the Hermann American Viticultural Area, whose seven wineries produce about one-third of the state's wine.
Designated in 1983, it is one of the first federally recognized American Viticultural Areas.
The designation recognized the renaissance of an area of vineyards and wineries established by Rhinelanders during the mid-19th century.
Shut down by Prohibition, it began to revive in the 1960s.
Hermann holds a Maifest during the third weekend in May and an Oktoberfest the first four weekends in October.
Hermann also calls itself the sausage-making capital of Missouri.
The John Siddles Williams House on Museum Street in Hermitage, on the National Register of Historic Places since 1980, houses the Hickory County Historical Society Museum and Research Room.
Greenwood Cemetery is located in Hillsdale.
Holts Summit is located 7 miles (11 km) northeast of Jefferson City, Missouri's state capital.

Hornersville is a city in Dunklin County, Missouri, United States, founded in 1840.
The Valentine Leight General Store and Moder Archeological District are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
The community is named after Adam House, who settled there ca.
A post office has been in operation at House Springs since 1833.

A center of activity in Huntsdale was Katfish Katy's, a small trail-side, seasonal restaurant along the Katy Trail State Park, until its closure in 2020.
The village was founded on August 1, 1892, and named after William Burch Hunt, a landowner.
Huntsdale was first incorporated in 1906, but that status eventually fell into neglect and the last village council election took place in 1929.
Due mainly to an influx of residential development in the area, Huntsdale was reincorporated in February 2003 and its first elections were held two months later.
As of the 2020 census, its population was 155.
Imperial was originally known as West Kimmswick, the historic Catholic church of St. John’s in Imperial, became an independent parish in 1869.
The city is sacred to the Latter Day Saint movement, as the home of Joseph Smith's 1831 Temple Lot, and the headquarters of several Mormon denominations.
Independence is known as the "Queen City of the Trails" because it was a point of departure for the California, Oregon, and Santa Fe Trails.
In 2020, it had a total population of 123011, making it the fifth-most populous city in Missouri.
A small part of the city extends into Clay County.
Innsbrook's largest lake so far.
The village of Innsbrook is comprised almost entirely by Innsbrook Resort—a private, gated community.
The village was founded in 1998.
The name “Innsbrook” was given to the village as a nod Austria’s Tyrol region, a place where beautiful A-frames can be found clustered around small lakes just like Innsbrook.
Construction began on a 236-acre Alpine Lake in 2000.
As of the 2020 census it had a population of 359, up from 309 in 2010.

Jefferson City is named for Thomas Jefferson (1743–1826), the third President of the United States, 1801–1809, and earlier major author of the Declaration of Independence of the United States on July 4, 1776.

Lewis and Clark with their Corps of Discovery passed the bluff here on their historic expedition upriver in 1804, eventually journeying westward to the Pacific Northwest region and the Pacific Ocean, before Europeans or Americans established any settlement there.

He also served several diplomatic posts overseas in Europe and was the first U S Secretary of State (1790–1793) in the first President's Cabinet of George Washington, and subsequently the second Vice President (1797–1801) under second chief executive John Adams.
The city is dominated by the monumental domed Missouri State Capitol, which rises from a bluff overlooking the nearby Missouri River to the north.
Many of Jefferson City's primary employers are in service and manufacturing industries like Hitachi.
Jefferson City, informally Jeff City, is the capital of the U S state of Missouri.
It had a population of 43228 at the 2020 United States census, ranking as the 16th most populous city in the state, but the 9th least populous U S state capital.
It forms part of the nine-county Columbia–Jefferson City–Moberly combined statistical area, which has 415747 residents.
Most of the city is located within Cole County, with a small northern section extending into adjacent Callaway County.
It is 29 miles (47 km) south of Columbia, Missouri, and sits at the western edge of the Missouri Rhineland, one of the major wine-producing regions of the Midwest.
Per the 2020 census, the population was 12895.
The bulk of the city is in Jasper County, while the southern portion is in Newton County.
With a population of 51762 as of the 2020 census, Joplin is the 12th most-populous city in the state.
In May 2011, a violent EF5 tornado killed more than 150 people and destroyed one-third of the city.
As of the 2020 census, its population was 1961.
With America's entry into World War I and the anti-German hysteria that followed, some residents proposed changing the name of the community to Success.
The community was named after the local Kaiser family.

Kansas City was founded in the 1830s as a port on the Missouri and Kansas rivers.

The city is composed of several neighborhoods, including the River Market District, 18th and Vine District, and the Country Club Plaza.
On June 1, 1850, the town of Kansas was incorporated; soon afterwards, a region designated as the Kansas Territory was established.
Confusion between the city and the territory of Kansas ensued, so the name Kansas City was assigned to distinguish the city from the territory.

Between 1990 and 2000, Kinloch lost more than 80 percent of its population, and the city became an increasingly violent and dangerous place to live.

The Treaties of Portage des Sioux in 1815 were signed here ostensibly settling Native American and United States conflicts in the War of 1812.

The treaties consolidated and affirmed the Treaty of St. Louis (1804) in which the Sauk and Meskwaki ceding northeast Missouri and much of Illinois and Wisconsin and the 1808 Treaty of Fort Clark in which the Osage Nation ceded all of Missouri and Arkansas.

Troy is an exurb of St. Louis, and is part of the St. Louis Metropolitan Statistical Area.

The former Village of Twin Oaks changed its status to that of a city by public election in November 2016.
The name Umber is derived from one Mr. Umber, the proprietor of an early-20th-century country store.
The Unity Village is a campus with historic buildings.
The Fillmores’ work was consolidated at Unity Village after World War II, and it is now the world headquarters for the ongoing spiritual movement.
The Tower and an office building then used for the Silent Unity Prayer Ministry opened in 1929 and are on the National Register of Historic Places.
Lake Charles R. Fillmore (named for the grandson of the Unity cofounders) was created in 1926 to supply water to the farm and orchard that Unity maintained until the 1980s.
A crew of 100 men built a concrete buttress dam, the only one of its kind in Missouri and one of the few west of the Mississippi River, at a cost of $100000 to form the lake.
It remains the primary water supply for the Village today, and its water is pumped to the on-campus water treatment plant.
Unity Village is also home to two artificial lakes.
The lake is 42 feet deep and covers 21 surface acres, holding about 75 million gallons of water.
Its population was 66 at the 2020 census.
The founders of the Unity spiritual movement, Charles and Myrtle Fillmore, purchased a 58-acre (23 ha) farm in 1919 as a weekend getaway for employees of their downtown Kansas City headquarters.
University City (colloquially, U. City) is an inner-ring suburb of the city of St. Louis in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States.
The village is one of many small majority black communities located in the Natural Bridge corridor of mid-St. Louis County, characterized by small homes on small lots.
Van Buren was founded in 1833 as the county seat of Ripley County and was named after then Vice President of the United States, Martin Van Buren.
In 1859, Van Buren became a part of the newly created Carter County and was subsequently selected to be the county seat.
The 2020 U S census showed Van Buren with a population of 747.

Walnut Shade is the site of the Branson Cross, the largest cross monument in North America.
Bonniebrook Homestead was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.
The town sits at the confluence of Bull and Bear Creeks.
A post office called Walnut Shade has been in operation since 1860.
The community once had Walnut Shade Schoolhouse, now defunct.
The name "Walnut Shade" is commendatory.
Wappapello was founded by Samuel R. Kelley, a veteran of the Civil War.
Wappapello was laid out in 1884 when the railroad was extended to that point.
He was originally from Ohio, saw the Wappapello area as a young Union soldier, and homesteaded land there after the war.
The community has the name of a Native American chieftain.

Warrenton is an exurb of St. Louis, and is located in the St. Louis Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Warrenton's slogan is "A City for All Seasons."
Adjacent to the Osage River it is heavily tied to two major lakes on the river.
The uppermost reaches of Lake of the Ozarks is part of southwest city limits and the Truman Dam and Truman Reservoir are on its northwest side.
The current town encompasses the sites of two communities formerly known as Keetsville and O'Day and is named for local pioneer Samuel C. Washburn.
It is notable for being the "corncob pipe capital of the world," with the Missouri Meerschaum located on the city's riverfront.
It is considered to be part of the Greater St. Louis area.
It is the westernmost settlement in the state of Missouri, about 120 miles northwest of Kansas City.
The Waverly Bridge over the Missouri River is located near here.
Waverly is the location of Baltimore Bend Winery, one of the many small wineries established in the state since the 1960s.
It is also home to General Jo Shelby, a hemp farmer who joined the Confederate cause in 1861.

Westphalia is heavily influenced by the German heritage of the majority of its inhabitants.
Many of the early settlers of the area came from the Westphalia region of Germany, hence the name.
Many buildings are influenced by nineteenth-century German architecture, and streets are labeled in both English and German.
The center of population of Missouri is located in Westphalia.

Zalma is home to a number of state parks that feature a number of activities such as deer hunting, fishing, bird watching, horseback riding, and hiking.
When the railroad moved to town, the name Bollinger's Mill was changed to Zalma, after railroad worker Zalma Block.
Zalma is also said to come from a Native American word meaning "the end." As of the 2020 U S census, Zalma had a population of 73.
Zalma is part of the Cape Girardeau−Jackson, MO-IL Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Blue Pond, the deepest natural pond in the state of Missouri, is located outside of Zalma.
